abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec><jats:title>Background</jats:title><jats:p>Germline mutations of breast cancer susceptibility gene<jats:italic>BRCA1</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>BRCA2</jats:italic>(<jats:italic>gBRCA1/2</jats:italic>) are associated with elevated risk of breast cancer in young women in Asia. BRCA1 and BRCA2 proteins contribute to genomic stability through homologous recombination (HR)-mediated double-strand DNA break repair in cooperation with other HR-related proteins. In this study, we analyzed the targeted sequencing data of Korean breast cancer patients with<jats:italic>gBRCA1/2</jats:italic>mutations to investigate the alterations in HR-related genes and their clinical implications.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Materials and methods</jats:title><jats:p>Data of the breast cancer patients with pathogenic<jats:italic>gBRCA1/2</jats:italic>mutations and qualified targeted next-generation sequencing, SNUH FiRST cancer panel, were analyzed. Single nucleotide polymorphisms, small insertions, and deletions were analyzed with functional annotations using ANNOVAR. HR-related genes were defined as<jats:italic>ABL1, ATM, ATR, BARD1, BRCA1, BRCA2, CDKN1A, CDKN2A, CHEK1, CHEK2, FANCA, FANCD2, FANCG, FANCI, FANCL, KDR, MUTYH, PALB2, POLE, POLQ, RAD50, RAD51, RAD51D, RAD54L,</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>. Mismatch-repair genes were<jats:italic>MLH1, MSH2</jats:italic>, and<jats:italic>MSH6</jats:italic>. Clinical data were analyzed with cox proportional hazard models and survival analyses.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results</jats:title><jats:p>Fifty-five Korean breast cancer patients with known<jats:italic>gBRCA1/2</jats:italic>mutations and qualified targeted NGS data were analyzed. Ethnically distinct mutations in<jats:italic>gBRCA1/2</jats:italic>genes were noted, with higher frequencies of Val1833Ser (14.8%), Glu1210Arg (11.1%), and Tyr130Ter (11.1%) in<jats:italic>gBRCA1</jats:italic>and Arg2494Ter (25.0%) and Lys467Ter (14.3%) in<jats:italic>gBRCA2.</jats:italic>Considering subtypes,<jats:italic>gBRCA1</jats:italic>mutations were associated with triple-negative breast cancers (TNBC), while<jats:italic>gBRCA2</jats:italic>mutations were more likely hormone receptor-positive breast cancers. At least one missense mutation of HR-related genes was observed in 44 cases (80.0%). The most frequently co-mutated gene was<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>(38.1%). In patients with<jats:italic>gBRCA1/2</jats:italic>mutations, however, genetic variations of<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>occurred in locations different from the known hotspots of those with sporadic breast cancers. The patients with both<jats:italic>gBRCA1/2</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>mutations were more likely to have TNBC, high Ki-67 values, and increased genetic mutations, especially of HR-related genes. Survival benefit was observed in the<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>mutants of patients with<jats:italic>gBRCA2</jats:italic>mutations, compared to those with<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>wild types.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title><jats:p>Our study showed genetic heterogeneity of breast cancer patients with<jats:italic>gBRCA1</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>gBRCA2</jats:italic>mutations in the Korean populations. Further studies on precision medicine are needed for tailored treatments of patients with genetic diversity among different ethnic groups.</jats:p></jats:sec>

group.label: Ethical approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study was approved by the Seoul National University Hospital (SNUH) Institutional Review Board (IRB No. H1509-047-702). Written informed consents were obtained from all participants before study. Clinical data were anonymized and de-identified before analysis.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
